questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of swelling and unusual heaviness of his scrotum that he first noticed a few weeks ago. The symptoms improve when he is lying in bed. He also reports a 5-kg weight loss and increasing fatigue over the past 6 months. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 15 years. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation of his right flank. There are soft strands palpable in the right hemiscrotum superior of the right testis. The strands increase with Valsalva maneuver. Applying a bright light to the right hemiscrotum shows no transillumination. Obstruction of venous drainage into which of the following vessels is most likely responsible for this patient's scrotal enlargement?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inferior vena cava

 

  • The patient has a right-sided varicocele (soft strands above testis, increases with Valsalva, non-transilluminating).
  • Sudden-onset or adult varicocele on the right side in a patient >40 years suggests secondary varicocele due to obstruction of venous drainage, commonly from retroperitoneal mass compressing the IVC (renal cell carcinoma, retroperitoneal tumor).
  • Right testicular vein drains directly into the IVC, whereas the left drains into the left renal vein. Hence IVC obstruction affects the right side predominantly.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Right internal iliac vein: Drains the pelvis; unlikely to cause isolated right-sided varicocele.

 

Option B. Right inferior rectal vein: Drains anorectal region; obstruction would cause hemorrhoids, not varicocele.

 

Option C. Right renal vein: Left-sided varicoceles are more commonly associated with left renal vein compression (Nutcracker syndrome), not right-sided.

questions.text: All of the following are correct about ACS guidelines for average-risk population for colorectal carcinoma except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Colonoscopy every 5 years

 

  • Reasoning:
  • According to ACS (American Cancer Society) guidelines for average-risk adults:
    • Start screening at 45–50 years
    • FOBT or FIT: annually
    • Flexible sigmoidoscopy: every 5 years
    • Colonoscopy: every 10 years, not 5 years
  • Colonoscopy allows visualization of the entire colon and polyp removal, so it is the preferred modality, but 10-year interval is recommended if normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Begin screening at 50 years: Correct. some guidelines now suggest 45 years.

 

Option B. Annual FOBT: Correct. non-invasive test for occult bleeding.

 

Option C. Flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 years: Correct. visualizes distal colon, can be combined with FOBT.

questions.text: A young female presents with pain in lower abdomen and vomiting in the ER. Clinical examination reveals a swelling, lateral and below the pubic tubercle. X-ray is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Strangulated femoral hernia

 

The clinical scenario and X-ray findings indicate a femoral hernia, which typically presents as a swelling below and lateral to the pubic tubercle. Associated pain, vomiting, and features of intestinal obstruction point toward strangulation, requiring urgent intervention.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Adhesions: Common cause of intestinal obstruction, but would not present as a groin swelling below the pubic tubercle.
 

Option B. Strangulated inguinal hernia: Swelling would be above and medial to the pubic tubercle, differing from the femoral hernia location.
 

Option D. Direct hernia: Occurs due to weakness in the abdominal wall, presenting as a swelling above the pubic tubercle, not below and lateral.

questions.text: Identify the fracture and mention the duration of below-knee POP cast applied for the following injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Jones fracture; 6-8 weeks

 

The X-ray shows a transverse fracture of the proximal diaphysis of the fifth metatarsal, consistent with a Jones fracture. This fracture is at high risk for delayed union or non-union due to poor blood supply, so immobilization with a below-knee POP (plaster of Paris) cast is required for 6–8 weeks to promote adequate healing and minimize complications.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Jones fracture; 2-3 weeks: Short duration is insufficient for healing and risks non-union.


Option B. Pseudo-Jones fracture; 3-5 weeks: Refers to an avulsion fracture of the tuberosity (styloid process), which heals faster and requires less immobilization.


Option D. Pseudo-Jones fracture; 6-8 weeks: Overly prolonged immobilization for an avulsion injury, which typically heals more quickly than a true Jones fracture.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements

 

  1. Liposarcoma is the most common retroperitoneal tumor.
  2. M3 midline hernia refers to epigastric hernia 
  3. A mesenteric cyst shows mobility perpendicular to line of mesenteric attachment.
  4. Colon cancer risk can be decreased by metformin
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3, 4

 

Statement 1. Liposarcoma is the most common retroperitoneal tumor: Correct. Liposarcoma is the most frequent primary malignant retroperitoneal soft tissue tumor, followed by leiomyosarcoma.

 

Statement 3. A mesenteric cyst shows mobility perpendicular to line of mesenteric attachment: Correct. Mesenteric cysts move freely at right angles to the root of mesentery, but not parallel to it (due to mesenteric tethering).

 

Statement 4. Colon cancer risk can be decreased by metformin: Correct. Several studies show that metformin reduces colon cancer risk in diabetics by improving insulin sensitivity and reducing hyperinsulinemia (which is a growth-promoting factor for colonic epithelium).

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 2. M3 midline hernia refers to epigastric hernia: Incorrect. According to the European Hernia Society classification, M3 = umbilical hernia. Epigastric hernia corresponds to M2.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. Forefoot adduction is the commonest residual deformity in CTEV
  2. Whitaker test is performed for Vesico-ureteric reflux. 
  3. Acute inflammation of colon is known as typhilitis.
  4. Duct ectasia may be associated with greenish nipple discharge.
questions.solution: Ans. B) 1, 4

questions.text: A child sustained a fracture after a fall. The post-op x-ray is shown below. The fracture will heal by which mechanism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Primary healing

 

The X-ray reveals a long bone fracture treated with rigid plating, bringing fracture ends into close contact and providing absolute stability. This setup allows the bone to heal through primary healing (direct bone healing), which involves remodelling of the Haversian systems across the fracture plane without visible callus formation. Cutting cones traverse the fracture line and new bone is laid down directly, provided movement at the fracture site is minimal.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Creeping substitution: Refers to the process of bone graft remodelling, not the mechanism of fracture healing itself.
 

Option B. Intramembranous ossification: Characterizes embryonic bone formation or some bone graft healing, not typical for direct fracture healing with rigid fixation.
 

Option D. Secondary healing: Involves callus formation and endochondral ossification, usually seen in fractures treated conservatively or with less rigid fixation.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with purulent discharge from an opening located in the perianal region. The patient is put in a lithotomy position and the opening is located at the 11 o'clock position, 4 cm from the anal margin. What will be the likely position of the internal opening?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 6 o'clock

 

  • Anorectal fistulas are commonly classified using Goodsall’s rule:
    1. External opening anterior to the transverse anal line → fistula tract runs straight into the anal canal.
    2. External opening posterior to the transverse anal line → fistula tract curves toward the posterior midline (6 o’clock position).
  • In this case, the external opening is posterior (11 o’clock) → the fistula tract starts at the internal opening in the posterior midline (6 o’clock).
  • This explains why most posterior fistulas have their internal opening at 6 o’clock, regardless of lateral position of the external opening.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 12 o’clock – Internal opening at anterior midline; only relevant for anterior external openings.

 

Option B. 11 o’clock – External opening position, not the internal opening; posterior external openings curve toward midline.

 

Option C. 9 o’clock – Lateral posterior, not typical according to Goodsall’s rule; most posterior fistulas terminate at 6 o’clock midline.

 

Goodsall rule:

questions.text: A young female patient complains of low back pain radiating to the right hip, back of the thigh, leg, and ankle after an intense workout of lifting some heavy weights. MRI shows the following finding. Which function will be weak here?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) EHL

 

Weakness of the Extensor Hallucis Longus (EHL) muscle is most commonly associated with L5 nerve root compression, which occurs frequently in lumbar disc herniation presenting as unilateral lower limb radiculopathy. The EHL is responsible for extending the big toe and assisting in dorsiflexion of the foot; its involvement produces difficulty in toe extension and clearing the foot during gait. This presentation strongly fits the described clinical scenario of pain radiating along the L5 dermatome, after heavy lifting, with classic MRI findings of disc pathology impinging the L5 root. Since EHL weakness is sensitive for L5 radiculopathy, focusing on this muscle in neurological exam aids localization and management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hip flexion: Hip flexion is primarily controlled by the iliopsoas muscle, innervated by L2–L3 nerve roots. Compression of L5 (as depicted by MRI and clinical findings) would not produce significant weakness in hip flexion.

 

Option B. Ankle dorsiflexion: Ankle dorsiflexion is mainly performed by the tibialis anterior muscle, predominantly L4 innervation, though some contribution from L5. Isolated L5 root compression more typically produces weakness of EHL rather than complete loss of ankle dorsiflexion, which is more severe in broader lesions.

 

Option D. Ankle plantar flexion: Plantar flexion of the ankle is executed by muscles like gastrocnemius and soleus, innervated by the S1 and S2 roots. L5 root compression does not cause plantar flexion weakness; S1 involvement would be required.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male with a history of a road traffic accident is brought to the emergency department. His GCS is 8/15, oxygen saturation is 85%, BP is 100/ 60 mmHg, and heart rate is 60 beats per minute. On auscultation his right side breath sounds were absent. What is the next step in management?

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. The most common complication of an untreated radial head dislocation is the cubitus valgus deformity at the elbow. 
  2. Seek kebab surgery / Sofield Miller Osteotomy is performed for Achondroplasia 
  3. Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) is elevated in osteoporosis
  4. Posterior tibialis tendon is palpable behind the medial malleolus during inversion of the foot
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3, 4

 

Statement 1. The most common complication of an untreated radial head dislocation is the cubitus valgus deformity at the elbow: Radial head dislocation untreated leads to cubitus valgus deformity.

 

Statement 3. Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) is elevated in osteoporosis: Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP), a marker of osteoclast activity, is elevated in osteoporosis due to increased bone resorption.

 

Statement 4. Posterior tibialis tendon is palpable behind the medial malleolus during inversion of the foot: Posterior tibialis tendon is palpable behind the medial malleolus during foot inversion.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 2. Seek kebab surgery / Sofield Miller Osteotomy is performed for Achondroplasia: Sheffield or Sofield-Miller osteotomy is used for bowed long bones in osteogenesis imperfecta[shown below], not achondroplasia.

Ileocolic, right colic, stem of middle colic, left colic
Ileocolic, right colic and trunk of middle colic

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient has been diagnosed with proximal ascending colon carcinoma. The physician recommends an right colectomy as a treatment option. Which arteries should be resected during an right colectomy?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Ileocolic, right colic and branch of middle colic

questions.text: Calculate for Burn Surface Area (BSA) for a patient with burn involving the anterior torso, upper right arm and circumferential right thigh:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 31.5% 

 

Calculation (adult, Rule of Nines / simple regional breakdown used):

 

  • Anterior torso = 18% (half of the trunk = 18%).
  • Upper right arm = 4.5% (whole arm = 9%, so upper arm ≈ half of the arm = 4.5%).
  • Circumferential right thigh = 9% (thigh ≈ half of the entire lower limb; whole lower limb = 18%, so thigh ≈ 9%).

 

Total = 18 + 4.5 + 9 = 31.5%.

 

Calculation of BSA in burns based on RULE OF NINES:

questions.text: A 1-month-old girl is brought to the OPD for a routine newborn examination.  Physical examination is shown below. When supine with the knees flexed, the left knee appears to be inferior to the right knee. Skin examination shows a nonblanching, blue-grey macule with indefinite borders over the sacrum. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ultrasound of hips 

 

The image and clinical scenario show asymmetric thigh folds and a left knee that is lower than the right when knees are flexed (Galeazzi sign), consistent with developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). In infants under 6 months, the most appropriate next step is ultrasound of the hips to assess hip joint integrity and positioning, because cartilage is not yet ossified and X-rays are less sensitive at this age.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Reassurance: Not appropriate due to signs suggestive of hip dysplasia requiring prompt investigation and intervention.
 

Option B. Skeletal survey: Indicated only if child abuse or metabolic bone disease is suspected, not in isolated DDH findings.
 

Option D. X-ray of hips: Not useful in infants under 6 months because femoral head and acetabulum are mostly cartilaginous at this age.

questions.text: An intra-operative image of scrotal exploration in a 18 year old male with acute scrotal pain is shown. Identify the pathology.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Torsion of Hydatid of Morgagni

 

The image shows a blue-black nodule (arrow) at the upper pole of the testis, which is characteristic of the torsion of the hydatid of Morgagni (appendix testis). This is a vestigial remnant and its torsion leads to acute scrotal pain, especially in adolescents.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Testicular torsion: Presents with twisted spermatic cord and non-viable, dusky testis, not limited to a small torsion nodule.
 

Option C. Epididymo-orchitis: Shows an enlarged, inflamed epididymis and testis but not a localized dark nodule.
 

Option D. Testicular hematoma: Appears as a collection of blood within the testis rather than a discrete nodule at the pole.

questions.text: All of the following are minimum standards for monitoring of a patient in shock except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Base deficit

 

Base deficit is an advanced laboratory marker of metabolic acidosis and tissue hypoperfusion, but it is not considered a minimum standard parameter for routine monitoring at the bedside for patients in shock.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. ECG: Essential for cardiac monitoring and rhythm assessment in shock.
 

Option B. Pulse oximetry: Mandatory for continuous monitoring of oxygen saturation in critically ill patients.
 

Option C. Urine output: Key indicator of end-organ perfusion and response to treatment, monitored via catheter.

 

ECG, pulse oximetry, and urine output are universally standard for shock monitoring; base deficit is not

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presented with severe abdominal pain and vomiting. His vitals are stable. He has a history of peptic ulcer disease. All of the following should be done except:
questions.solution: Ans. C) UGIE

questions.text: A patient who sustained blunt abdominal trauma after a road accident is admitted to the ICU overnight. He is hemodynamically stable. On abdominal examination, he now has tenderness, rigidity, and rebound tenderness. Which is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Laparotomy

 

  • The patient now shows signs of peritonitis (tenderness, rigidity, rebound), indicating intra-abdominal injury requiring surgical intervention.
  • Even though he was initially stable, the onset of peritoneal signs mandates immediate laparotomy to identify and control internal bleeding or organ injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Conservative management – Appropriate only in hemodynamically stable patients without peritoneal signs or organ injury that can be monitored safely. Not suitable once peritonitis develops.

 

Option C. eFAST (extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma) – Useful in initial assessment for free fluid/hemoperitoneum, but cannot replace surgery when peritonitis is evident.

 

Option D. Diagnostic peritoneal lavage – Historically used to detect intra-abdominal bleeding; largely superseded by CT or eFAST in stable patients, and unnecessary when clear peritoneal signs indicate immediate laparotomy.

choices.text: Broad spectrum antibiotics to cover GNB

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with weight loss and fever. The patient reports a history of blood in the stool and vomiting two weeks ago. Upon examination, tenderness is noted in the right hypochondrium along with an enlarged liver. An abdominal CT scan is shown below. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Start metronidazole

 

The CT scan shows a liver lesion with characteristic peripheral enhancement and central hypodensity, consistent with an amoebic liver abscess. The most appropriate initial management is to start metronidazole, which is highly effective against Entamoeba histolytica.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Broad spectrum antibiotics to cover GNB: Indicated for pyogenic liver abscess (bacterial), not amoebic.


Option C. PAIR (Puncture, Aspiration, Injection, Re-aspiration): Appropriate for hydatid cysts, not amoebic abscess.


Option D. Pigtail drainage: Reserved for large abscesses at risk of rupture or not responding to medical therapy.

questions.text: A 58-year-old lady with a previous history of WLE for DCIS presents to the OPD with complaints of a firmness in the region of the scar without a palpable lump. What is the next best step in this case?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Perform MRI

questions.text: Reynold’s pentad includes all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hematemesis 

 

Reynold’s pentad is seen in severe acute suppurative cholangitis and includes:

 

  1. Charcot’s triad – fever, jaundice, right upper quadrant pain
  2. PENTAD: TRIAD + Hypotension (shock) + Altered mental status (confusion)

 

Hematemesis is not a feature; it suggests upper gastrointestinal bleeding (e.g., varices, peptic ulcer).

choices.text: Infant is at least 10 weeks old
Hemoglobin level of 10 grams per deciliter

questions.text: Millard's Rule of 10 for indications of cleft lip surgery include all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Defect is 10 mm

 

  • Millard’s Rule of 10 is a safety guideline for timing cleft lip repair:
  1. Age ≥ 10 weeks
  2. Weight ≥ 10 pounds (~4.5 kg)
  3. Hemoglobin ≥ 10 g/dL
  • There is no criterion regarding the size of the cleft (10 mm).
  • The rule ensures the infant is physiologically stable to tolerate anesthesia and surgery safely.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Infant is at least 10 weeks old: Correct, ensures adequate maturity and reduced anesthesia risk.

 

Option B. Infant weighs around 10 pounds: Correct, adequate weight reduces perioperative complications.

 

Option C. Hemoglobin level of 10 grams per deciliter: Correct, ensures sufficient oxygen-carrying capacity during surgery.

questions.text: Identify what is depicted in the abdominal X-Ray.
questions.solution: Ans. B) Retrograde pyelogram

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the ERCP image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biliary ascariasis

 

The ERCP image typically shows elongated, linear filling defects within the biliary ducts, consistent with the presence of adult Ascaris worms. This is characteristic of biliary ascariasis, where the parasite migrates into the bile ducts causing biliary obstruction.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Choledochal cyst: Would show cystic dilatation of the bile ducts rather than linear filling defects.

 

Option C. Caroli disease: Characterized by saccular or fusiform intrahepatic bile duct dilatation with a "central dot" sign, not seen as linear intraductal filling defects.


Option D. Choledocholithiasis: Shows discrete filling defects caused by calculi, which are usually round or oval, not elongated like worms.

 

Thus, the diagnosis based on ERCP findings is biliary ascariasis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to the emergency department with a progressively worsening constellation of neurological and psychiatric symptoms. Her family reports that she had been experiencing personality changes, mood swings, and memory difficulties for the past few weeks. Neurological examination reveals hyperactive deep tendon reflexes and a generalized tremor.  The chest X-ray is shown here. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Germ cell tumor

On examination, there is a visible bruise over his lower abdomen, and blood is seen at the urethral meatus. The bladder is not palpable. What is the appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Anterior laxity of the tibia relative to the femur
Excessive valgus deviation with lower leg abduction
Painful click during knee extension and external rotation
Tenderness at the medial knee below the joint line

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the AIIMS OPD due to right knee pain for the past 3 days. She was carrying a heavy backpack on a muddy trail when she tripped, twisting her leg. The next morning, she had swelling at the knee and significant medial knee pain with stairs and squatting. Which of the following is most likely to be found on examination of this patient's knee?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Painful click during knee extension and external rotation 

 

This scenario describes a twisting injury with immediate pain and swelling localized to the medial aspect of the knee. The most likely injury is a medial meniscus tear, which commonly presents with joint line pain, swelling, and mechanical symptoms like locking, popping, or a painful click. The McMurray test, performed with external rotation of the tibia and extension of the knee, elicits this painful click, which is diagnostic of medial meniscus injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior laxity of the tibia relative to the femur: This finding is typical of an anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury and is detected with the Lachman or anterior drawer test. ACL tears usually occur with a popping sensation at the time of injury and lead to immediate hemarthrosis, rather than isolated medial joint pain.

 

Option B. Excessive valgus deviation with lower leg abduction: This indicates medial collateral ligament (MCL) injury, which occurs due to force pushing the knee inward (valgus stress). Pain is localized at the medial aspect of the knee at the ligament site, but mechanical clicking during movement is not seen.

 

Option D. Tenderness at the medial knee below the joint line: This suggests pes anserine bursitis, an inflammation of the bursa beneath the conjoined tendons of the sartorius, gracilis, and semitendinosus. It presents with localized medial pain below the joint, often in overweight women or athletes, but does not produce clicks or mechanical symptoms.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented to the dermatologist with a small lesion on her right nasolabial fold. Upon examination, the dermatologist noted a 0.4-cm nodule with a smooth surface and well-defined borders. It was excised and a pathological examination was done. The image is given below. What is the diagnosis?

questions.text: What other finding would be expected in this 25-year-old male with abnormal pelvis MRI?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute painful red eye

 

This MRI image demonstrates bilateral sacroiliitis, a hallmark of ankylosing spondylitis, particularly in young men. Ankylosing spondylitis is frequently associated with extra-articular manifestations, most notably acute anterior uveitis, which presents as an acute painful red eye with photophobia and blurred vision. The connection is because both sacroiliitis and uveitis are seronegative spondyloarthropathy features and often co-exist in affected patients. Recognizing the ocular involvement is crucial in evaluating systemic disease activity and providing holistic management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elevated RF: Rheumatoid factor (RF) is typically negative in ankylosing spondylitis and other seronegative spondyloarthropathies. The absence of RF helps differentiate it from rheumatoid arthritis, making this finding unlikely.

 

Option C. Atlanto-axial dislocation: Atlanto-axial dislocation is classically seen in advanced rheumatoid arthritis or juvenile idiopathic arthritis, not in ankylosing spondylitis. Although cervical spine involvement (like fusion) is seen later in AS, dislocation is rare.

 

Option D. IV disc calcification: Intervertebral disc calcification is usually associated with degenerative spinal diseases or metabolic conditions, not with ankylosing spondylitis or sacroiliitis. AS typically causes syndesmophyte formation and spinal ankylosis  but not disc calcification

questions.text: Which of the following will you not be taking into consideration while calculating the ASEPSIS score?

choices.text: Left gastric vein and azygos vein
Paraumbilical vein and inferior epigastric vein
Portal vein and inferior vena cava
Splenic vein and left renal vein

questions.text: A 57-year-old white man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance because of sudden-onset, bright red emesis. His blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg and heart rate is 124/min. Physical examination is notable for jaundice and an enlarged abdomen that is dull to percussion and positive for a fluid wave. Which of the following vessel anastomoses is responsible for the patient’s bleeding?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left gastric vein and azygos vein

 

  • The patient has hematemesis in the setting of portal hypertension (jaundice, ascites).
  • Esophageal varices are the most common cause of upper GI bleeding in cirrhosis.
  • Esophageal varices arise from portosystemic anastomosis between the left gastric vein (portal system) and azygos vein (systemic circulation).
  • Rupture leads to massive, bright red hematemesis and hypovolemic shock.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Paraumbilical vein and inferior epigastric vein: Form caput medusae; superficial abdominal varices, rarely bleed massively.

 

Option C. Portal vein and inferior vena cava: There is no direct anastomosis causing variceal bleeding; portal hypertension leads to collateral formation instead.

 

Option D. Splenic vein and left renal vein: Forms gastric or short gastric varices; less common and usually in splenic vein thrombosis, not general cirrhosis.

A FLR (future liver remnant) of at least 40% normal liver is a pre-requisite for resection

questions.text: A trauma patient suffered a renal laceration with urine extravasation. He was managed conservatively. However, after a few days, he presented with a urinoma. The next best management for this patient would be:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ureteral stenting

 

  • Urinoma is a collection of urine in the retroperitoneum due to urine leak after renal trauma.
  • First-line management in a hemodynamically stable patient with urinary extravasation is internal urinary diversion via ureteral stent placement.
  • This allows urine to bypass the site of injury, promotes healing, and prevents infection or further collection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Surgical repair and exploration: Surgical repair is reserved for severe injuries with persistent leak despite stenting or associated vascular/collecting system injury.

 

Option D. Pigtail drainage of collection: Percutaneous drainage (pigtail) is usually adjunctive if the urinoma is infected. 

 

Option C. Observation: Observation alone is insufficient if the urinoma is enlarging or symptomatic.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. Proper functioning of an ICD tube is checked by presence of oscillating movement of the water column. 
  2. A green cannula is the minimum size recommended for adult trauma patients 
  3. 1g tranexamic acid bolus is given to all patients of trauma in shock. 
  4. NG tube is measured from ala of the nose to the ear lobule to the xiphisternum.
questions.solution: Ans. C) 1, 2, 3

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented to the clinic with complaints of pain and swelling in the right side of his face. Upon examination, the physician noted swelling in the submandibular gland. The patient also reported that his symptoms worsened when he ate food, and he had lost his appetite due to the discomfort. USG is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sialolithiasis

 

The ultrasound image shows a hyperechoic structure with posterior acoustic shadowing within the right submandibular duct, indicating a salivary stone (sialolith). This finding, combined with symptoms of pain and swelling that worsen during meals, is classic for sialolithiasis.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Pleomorphic adenoma: Usually presents as a well-defined, hypoechoic, solid mass in the gland, not a calcified lesion in the duct.
 

Option C. Osteoma of floor of mouth: Rare, and would be seen as a dense bony structure, not within the submandibular duct.
 

Option D. Cervical lymphadenopathy: Appears as enlarged, rounded lymph nodes in the cervical chain, unrelated to ductal stones.

questions.text: Identify the incision made and marked is the image:
questions.solution: Ans. A) Clamshell

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman experiences an increased frequency of micturition, with pain relieved by micturition and aggravated by overdistension of the bladder. Urine routine tests showed no pus cells and cystoscopy revealed fissures and punctate hemorrhages in the bladder mucosa as shown in the image below. What is the most probable clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Interstitial cystitis

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the skeletal survey of a 10-year-old boy with recurrent fractures?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Osteopetrosis

questions.text: A 7 month old baby boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to “empty scrotum”. On examination, hemiscrotum on right side is not developed and testis is not palpable in the inguinal region. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diagnostic laparoscopy

 

In a 7-month-old infant with non-palpable undescended testis and absent hemiscrotum, diagnostic laparoscopy is the next step. It helps to locate an intra-abdominal or blind-ending testis and plan further management.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. HCG test dose: Used for cryptorchidism but usually at an older age and when testis is palpable.
 

Option C. Reassurance: Not appropriate without confirming the location of the testis in non-palpable cases.
 

Option D. Inguinal exploration: Considered if testis is palpable in the inguinal canal but not detected on laparoscopy.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease undergoes coronary artery bypass surgery. His postoperative course is complicated by hypotension, which is treated successfully with intravenous fluids; however, a few hours later, he experiences severe abdominal pain followed by bloody diarrhea.  Abdominal examination shows normal bowel sounds, with no significant guarding or focal tenderness. The venous lactic acid level is elevated.  An abdominal CT scan is ordered which shows edema at the anastomotic bridging between the right and left terminal branches of the ascending left colic artery. What is this point referred to as?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Griffith point

questions.text: The injury shown in the radiograph can result in:
questions.solution: Ans. A) ACL injury

questions.text: Identify the size of the given blade
questions.solution: Ans. B) 11

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presented to the OPD with a scald injury on his arm. The lesion was pink, oozing, and painful to moving air and touch. Which of the following would be the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Paraffin gauze dressing

 

  • This patient has a superficial partial-thickness burn, as indicated by pink, moist, oozing skin and pain on touch/air movement.
  • Management:
    • Non-adherent dressings such as paraffin gauze or hydrocolloid dressings are ideal to maintain a moist environment, prevent infection, and allow pain-free dressing changes.
    • Healing usually occurs in 7–14 days without grafting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silver sulphadiazine cream dressing: Historically used, but it forms a pseudoeschar and adheres to the wound, making dressing changes painful. Not ideal for superficial partial-thickness burns.

 

Option B. Excision and grafting: Reserved for deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns, typically when spontaneous healing is unlikely (>3 weeks) or in large areas.

 

Option D. Collagen dressing: Useful in full thickness burns, chronic wounds, or donor sites

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with a thyroid nodule. Serum TSH is normal. Ultrasound of her thyroid reveals a 1.5-cm hypoechoic nodule in the right thyroid lobe with irregular margins, internal microcalcifications, and internal vascularity. FNAC is performed which is reported as Thy3 Bethesda grade. Which of the following is the next most appropriate step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hemi-thyroidectomy 

 

Thy3 / Bethesda III corresponds to follicular lesion of undetermined significance or follicular neoplasm, with a 10–30% risk of malignancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeat FNAC: May be considered in some Thy3 nodules, but suspicious ultrasound features and patient preference usually favor diagnostic surgery.

 

Option B. MRI of the neck: Not indicated for evaluation of thyroid nodules; it is reserved for large, invasive, or retrosternal masses or for staging.

 

Option D. RAIU scan: Useful only if TSH is suppressed to differentiate “hot” vs “cold” nodules; in euthyroid patients, a cold nodule on RAIU may indicate higher malignancy risk, but ultrasound + FNAC already guides management here.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman complains of fatigue, weight gain, and increased sensitivity to cold. On physical examination, she has noticeable swelling in her neck. The histological image is shown below. Additionally, an ultrasound examination shows that her thyroid gland is diffusely enlarged and has an uneven texture. Which of the following conditions is most likely the cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hashimoto’s thyroiditis 

 

The histological image reveals lymphoid follicles with germinal centers and abundant lymphocytic infiltration within the thyroid parenchyma. Clinically, the patient displays symptoms of hypothyroidism, a diffusely enlarged and heterogeneous thyroid gland, and the classical histopathology of Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MTC (Medullary thyroid carcinoma): Characterized by spindle-shaped or polygonal cells, amyloid stroma, and not prominent lymphoid infiltration.


Option B. de-Quervian thyroiditis: Presents with granulomatous inflammation and giant cells, not lymphoid follicles.

 

 

Option C. Grave's disease: Shows tall columnar follicular cells, scalloped colloid, and increased vascularity, not lymphocytic infiltration and germinal centers.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman receives neo-adjuvant chemotherapy for invasive ductal carcinoma. Clinical assessment shows that the tumor has shrunk to 3 cm on mammography with no nodal involvement or metastasis. Which of the following accurately represents the current staging?
questions.solution: Ans. B) уT2N0M0

questions.text: What could be the possible diagnosis of a 35-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension and multiple episodes of hematuria and bilateral loin pain, whose elder brother passed away due to stroke at the age of 40 and whose ultrasound abdomen is shown below?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with right heel pain since 3 months. She is a model by profession. There is no history of trauma. What is the likely diagnosis based on the MRI STIR image shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Haglund deformity

 

The MRI STIR image of the heel displays increased signal intensity (edema) at the posterosuperior aspect of the calcaneus, with a characteristic bony prominence located where the Achilles tendon inserts. This is classic for Haglund deformity ("pump bump"), commonly caused by repeated irritation from high-heeled or snug shoes, seen most often in young women and models. Associated findings on MRI include retrocalcaneal bursitis and thickening of the Achilles tendon, which can cause chronic posterior heel pain without trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Madelung deformity: Madelung deformity is a congenital wrist abnormality characterized by volar subluxation of the wrist and bowing of the distal radius, not associated with heel pain or calcaneal changes. It is easily excluded by the location and the imaging findings.

 

 

Option C. Plantar fasciitis: Plantar fasciitis typically presents with pain at the inferior heel, especially on first steps in the morning, and involves the plantar fascia origin on imaging. The MRI would show thickening and edema along the plantar fascia, not at the posterosuperior calcaneus.

 

Option D. Stress fracture: Stress fracture of the calcaneus would be identified by focal bone marrow edema and sometimes a visible fracture line, usually appearing at sites of repetitive impact or in athletes. The MRI appearance and clinical history here are more typical of Haglund deformity.

choices.text: Entrapment of the posterior tibial nerve

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the OPD for evaluation of new-onset foot pain. The pain is located at the heel and is most pronounced when she gets up from sitting after a long period of time. She enjoys running every evening for one hour. Direct pressure to the bottom of the heel elicits sharp pain, but mediolateral squeezing of the heel causes no discomfort. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of the patient's foot pain?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inflammation of the plantar aponeurosis

 

Plantar fasciitis is the most frequent cause of heel pain, especially in runners and athletes. Pain is worst with initial steps after a period of rest and with direct pressure at the medial calcaneal tuberosity. MRI and clinical exam differentiate it from stress fractures and nerve entrapment: mediolateral squeezing does not elicit pain here. Underlying etiology is microtrauma and inflammation at the plantar fascia origin from chronic overuse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Entrapment of the posterior tibial nerve: Tarsal tunnel syndrome causes tingling, numbness, burning at the sole; pain increases on tapping the nerve (Tinel’s sign).

 

Option B. Morton neuroma: Located between the toes, not the heel, causing burning and numbness and pain on squeezing the forefoot (Mulder’s sign).

 

Option C. Stress fracture: Typically produces pain on mediolateral squeeze of the heel and is less circumscribed than plantar fasciitis.

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate presented with recurrent bilious vomiting. An X-ray erect abdomen is shown below. What is the next best step in managing this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gastrograffin follow-through 

 

The abdominal X-ray in a neonate with recurrent bilious vomiting shows multiple air-fluid levels and a double bubble sign, suggestive of duodenal obstruction or malrotation with volvulus. The next best step is a contrast (Gastrograffin) follow-through study to delineate the anatomy and confirm the level and cause of obstruction before surgical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Upper GI endoscopy: Not indicated acutely for initial evaluation of neonatal obstruction.

 

Option C. Air enema: Used for intussusception, not for duodenal or proximal small bowel obstruction in neonates.

 

Option D. Explorative laparotomy: Reserved for cases with confirmed diagnosis or evidence of bowel compromise; not the immediate next investigation.

Identify the correct statements

 

  1. Stage IV in Hinchey's classification corresponds to fecal peritonitis
  2. Surgery is recommended for asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysms when the diameter reaches 55mm or greater. 
  3. The most common site of an intra-abdominal abscess is subhepatic space.
  4. Fecal discharge from the umbilicus in a child is indicative of a patent urachus
questions.solution: Ans. C) 1, 2, 3

questions.text: A patient presents with a tender pulsatile mass as shown in the image below. What is the next step?
questions.solution: Ans. C) CT angiogram

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented with a noticeable swelling in his scrotum. After careful evaluation, a decision was made to perform an orchidectomy. The histopathological examination of the tissue reveals the following findings. Based on these findings which of the following diagnoses best describes the patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Seminoma

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with suspected thoracic outlet syndrome is being examined. Hyperabduction of the arm on the affected side causes a reduction in the radial artery pulsation. X-ray is shown below. What is this test known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wright's test

 

Hyperabduction of the arm causing diminished radial artery pulsation is known as the Wright's test (Hyperabduction test), which helps diagnose thoracic outlet syndrome. During this maneuver, the shoulder is abducted above 90° and externally rotated, compressing the neurovascular structures beneath the pectoralis minor muscle and axilla. A positive test results in reduced radial pulse or reproduction of neurovascular symptoms on the affected side, commonly in patients with structural anomalies such as a cervical rib as seen on the attached X-ray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adson's test: Adson's test involves extension, abduction, and external rotation of the arm with the patient’s head turned towards the affected side and deep inspiration. It checks for subclavian artery compression at the interscalene triangle and was historically used for cervical rib assessment.

 

Option B. Halstead's maneuver: Halstead's maneuver uses downward traction on the arm, abduction, external rotation, and turning the head away from the affected side. It is another provocative test for thoracic outlet syndrome focusing on costoclavicular compression[shown below].

 

Option C. Roos's test: Roos's test (Elevated Arm Stress Test) requires the patient to hold the "surrender" position and repeatedly open/close the palms for 3 minutes. The test is positive if pain or paresthesia develops, stressing all intervals of the neurovascular bundle.

choices.text: a, b, c, d are correct

questions.text:
Evaluate the following statements with respect to intertrochanteric fracture: (AIIMS Nov 2019)

 

  1. More common in males than females.
  2. 1 year mortality rate is 20-30%.
  3. It is more commonly associated with nonunion than fracture neck of femur.
  4. 1 year mortality can be reduced by operating within 48 hours.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) b and d are correct.

 

Explanation:

 

INTERTROCHANTERIC FRACTURE FEMUR

 

  • Intertrochanteric fractures are extracapsular fractures of the proximal femur that occur between the greater and lesser trochanter.
  • This metaphyseal region has a more abundant blood supply, contributing to a higher union rate and less osteonecrosis compared to femoral neck fractures.
  • Etiology:
    • These fractures occur both in the elderly and the young, but they are more common in the elderly population with osteoporosis due to a low energy mechanism. 
    • The female to male ration is between 2:1 and 8:1.
    • In the younger population, these fractures typically result from a high-energy mechanism.
  • These patients present with a short and externally rotated limb.
  • Treatment:

 

 

  • Treatment of choice: Dynamic Hip Screw (Undisplaced fracture).
  • Displaced fracture: Proximal femoral nail (Cephalomedullary nail).
  • Latest literature claims better results with Proximal Femoral Nail (PFN).
  • Most common complication is malunion.
  • 1 year mortality rate is 20-30%.
  • 1 year mortality can be reduced by operating within 48 hours.

 

INTERTROCHANTERIC FRACTURE VS NECK OF FEMUR FRACTURE

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intertrochanteric fracture is more common in females than males.
  • Most common complication is malunion.
  • 1 year mortality rate is 20-30%.
  • 1 year mortality can be reduced by operating within 48 hours.

questions.solution: Ans. B) Check for prophylactic antibiotic administration

questions.text: The index shown in the image below is useful for planning management of which condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Scoliosis

 

The index shown in the image is the Risser sign (or Risser index), which assesses the ossification of the iliac apophysis. This index is primarily used to evaluate skeletal maturity and predict the risk of progression in adolescent idiopathic scoliosis. The information is crucial for planning bracing, follow-up intervals, and surgical timing in scoliosis management. It is not applied in the management of DDH, ankylosing spondylitis, or AVN

questions.text: In extended right hemi-hepatectomy, the liver segments resected are:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4-8

 

  • Couinaud’s classification divides the liver into 8 segments (1 = caudate lobe).
  • Right hepatectomy = removal of segments 5, 6, 7, 8.
  • Extended right hepatectomy (also called right trisectionectomy) = removal of segments 4, 5, 6, 7, 8.
    • Includes both right lobe + segment 4 (medial left lobe).
    • Leaves behind segments 1, 2, 3.
  • Other resections for context:
    • Left hepatectomy = 2, 3, 4
    • Extended left hepatectomy = 2, 3, 4, 5, 8
    • Central hepatectomy = 4, 5, 8

questions.solution: Ans. B) Adenocarcinoma is a rare variant of rectal carcinoma

questions.solution: Ans. D) 6%

questions.text:
Identify the incorrect statements:

 

  1. Tom smith arthritis most commonly affects the femoral capital epiphysis. 
  2. De Quervain’s tenosynovitis is the inflammation of the tendons of abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis. 
  3. Non-articular pain occurs only during passive movements.
  4. Singh’s Index is used for TB grading.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3, 4

 

3. Non-articular pain occurs only during passive movements: Incorrect. In non-articular disorders, pain occurs mainly during active movements (because periarticular structures are involved). Pain is usually not restricted to passive movement.

 

4. Singh’s Index is used for TB grading: Incorrect. Singh’s Index is used for grading osteoporosis on X-rays of the proximal femur, not for TB.

 

Correct statements:

 

1. Tom Smith arthritis most commonly affects the femoral capital epiphysis: Correct. Tom Smith arthritis = tubercular arthritis of the hip in children. It indeed affects the femoral head/epiphysis.

 

2. De Quervain’s tenosynovitis: Correct. It is inflammation of Abductor pollicis longus (APL) + Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) tendons at the radial styloid → correctly stated.

  1. DEXA

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a reddish, firm nodule on her chest that has not increased in size. The patient is concerned about the possibility of malignancy and undergoes a biopsy of the lesion. Histopathological examination of the biopsy specimen shows certain features that aid in the diagnosis. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Hemangioma

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presented to the trauma centre after an RTA. He complained of severe pain in the left upper abdomen. On examination, there was presence of non-shifting dullness in LUQ. What is this sign called?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Ballance sign

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements with respect to CTEV. 

 

  1. 50% cases are bilateral with male predominance 
  2. Forefoot is adducted and supinated
  3. Ponsetti technique is preferred for correction 
  4. Adduction should be corrected first
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

Statements 1, 2, and 3 are all correct regarding Congenital Talipes Equinovarus (CTEV), also known as clubfoot. 

 

  • About 50% of cases are bilateral, with a strong male predominance—male to female ratio ranging from approximately 2:1 to 3:1. 
  • The forefoot is adducted and supinated—the classic clubfoot position, with inversion and equinus of the hindfoot. 
  • The Ponsetti technique is the gold standard for correction and has almost replaced older methods due to its high success rate and low recurrence. 
  • The correction sequence in Ponsetti technique always emphasizes Cavus first (CAVE).

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with rectal bleeding, a change in bowel habits, and tenesmus for 6 months. Examination reveals a mass in the rectum 2 cm from the anal verge extending to the anal sphincters, and biopsy confirms adenocarcinoma. What surgical intervention is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Abdominoperineal resection

 

For a rectal adenocarcinoma located within 2 cm of the anal verge and involving the anal sphincters, abdominoperineal resection (APR) is the most appropriate surgical intervention. This procedure involves removal of the rectum, anus, and surrounding tissues with permanent colostomy, ensuring oncologic clearance.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Total mesorectal excision: A surgical technique used as part of low anterior resection or APR but not a standalone procedure.

 

 

Option B. Low anterior resection: Suitable for tumors located higher in the rectum where sphincter preservation is possible.


Option D. Hartmann's procedure: Typically done for obstructed or perforated sigmoid colon, not for low rectal cancers involving sphincters.

choices.text: Commonly presents in the 20-40 years age group
Osteoclast giant cells constitute the proliferative component of the tumor

questions.solution: Ans. C) Osteoclast giant cells constitute the proliferative component of the tumor

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based in the given X-ray?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fibrous dysplasia

 

The X-ray displays a well-defined, expansile intramedullary lesion in the proximal femur, surrounded by a thick, sclerotic margin—the “rind sign”. This sign is classic for fibrous dysplasia, which replaces normal bone with fibrous tissue and reactive woven bone, leading to the ground-glass matrix and thick sclerotic border that differentiates it from other bone lesions. The rind sign is most frequently seen in the femur but can be present elsewhere, and its identification is highly specific for fibrous dysplasia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ABC (Aneurysmal Bone Cyst): ABC is an expansile, lytic, blood-filled bone lesion often showing fluid-fluid levels and a thin sclerotic rim, not a thick continuous rind. It appears more locally destructive and without the ground-glass matrix.

 

 

Option B. SBC (Simple Bone Cyst/Unicameral Bone Cyst): SBC typically presents as a centrally located, unicameral cyst in the metaphysis of long bones, with thin cortex and absent sclerotic rind. It rarely causes marked bone expansion or a thick sclerotic margin. Classical sign = Fallen Fragment sign[shown below]

 

 

Option D. Enchondroma: Enchondroma is a benign cartilage tumor that forms a well-defined, centrally located, lucent lesion in small bones (especially hands) with stippled calcification, not with a rind sign or femoral predilection.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and vomiting. The child's parents mention that the pain has been increasing over the past few hours. On examination, the child appears distressed and has abdominal tenderness. An X-ray is ordered, and it reveals a gasless abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute Pancreatitis 

 

The clinical presentation of severe abdominal pain and vomiting, along with a gasless abdomen on X-ray, suggests acute pancreatitis. Gasless abdomen is a known radiological sign in early or severe pancreatitis due to paralytic ileus.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Appendicitis: Typically presents with localized right lower quadrant pain; gasless abdomen is uncommon.
 

Option B. Intussusception: Shows characteristic signs like “target sign” on ultrasound and sometimes air-fluid levels on X-ray, not gasless abdomen.
 

Option D. Crohn's disease: Chronic condition with thickened bowel loops; gasless abdomen is not a common feature.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient with squamous cell carcinoma of the neck undergoes radical neck dissection. Which of the following structures is typically spared during this procedure?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Digastric muscle

questions.text: A young woman presented to the OPD with dysphagia and regurgitation of food. She was diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia 3 months back. Barium swallow was done and is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Plummer-Vinson Syndrome

 

The barium swallow image shows a cervical esophageal web resulting in partial obstruction, and the clinical context includes dysphagia, regurgitation, and a history of iron deficiency anemia. These findings are classic for Plummer-Vinson syndrome[aka Patterson Kelley Syndrome]

 

Other Options:


Option A. Shatzki ring: Typically a lower esophageal (distal) web, not in the cervical esophagus, and not associated with iron deficiency anemia.

 

 

Option B. Zenker's diverticulum: Seen as a posterior outpouching in the pharyngoesophageal area, presenting with regurgitation and halitosis.

 

 

Option C. Esophageal leiomyoma: Appears as a smooth, submucosal mass on imaging, not as a thin mucosal web.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. Annual risk of adenocarcinoma in Barrett’s esophagus with low grade dysplasia is 0.7% per year.
  2. The iliohypogastric nerve is most commonly injured during Rutherford-Morrison incision
  3. Replaced left hepatic artery arising from superior mesenteric artery is the most common vascular anomaly of the liver. 
  4. Malignant melanoma in the last 5 years is a contraindication to renal transplant
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4

 

Statement 1. Annual risk of adenocarcinoma in Barrett’s esophagus with low-grade dysplasia is 0.7% per year: Correct. Barrett’s esophagus with low-grade dysplasia carries a modest but significant risk of progression to adenocarcinoma (~0.5–1% per year).

 

Statement 2. The iliohypogastric nerve is most commonly injured during Rutherford-Morrison incision: Correct. The Rutherford-Morrison incision (used for lower abdominal/pelvic surgeries) crosses the course of the iliohypogastric nerve, making it the most commonly injured nerve in this approach.

 

Statement 4. Malignant melanoma in the last 5 years is a contraindication to renal transplant: Correct.Recent history of aggressive malignancy, especially melanoma, is a contraindication to immunosuppression due to high risk of recurrence.

 

Incorrect statement:

 

Statement 3. Replaced left hepatic artery arising from SMA is the most common vascular anomaly of the liver: Incorrect. The most common hepatic arterial anomaly is a replaced right hepatic artery arising from the superior mesenteric artery.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man came with complaints of dark-colored tarry stools to the OPD. Which of the following structures is the likely site of the bleed?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Proximal to Ligament of Treitz

 

The image shows melena (dark tarry stool), which is caused by upper gastrointestinal bleeding. The color results from the action of digestive enzymes and bacteria on hemoglobin as blood passes through the GI tract, indicating the source lies proximal to the ligament of Treitz (duodenojejunal flexure).

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Distal to Ligament of Treitz: Bleeding from this region usually presents as hematochezia (fresh blood in stool) rather than melena.
 

Option C. Anal canal: Bleeding here results in bright red blood per rectum.
 

Option D. Sigmoid diverticulosis: Typically causes painless lower GI bleeding, presenting as hematochezia, not melena.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male having pain and deformity of the tibia as shown in X-ray. He had history of trauma 2 years back. What is the most probable diagnosis?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic osteomyelitis

 

CHRONIC OSTEOMYELITIS

 

  • Usually a sequela of inadequately treated acute osteomyelitis.
  • Causative organism: staphylococcus aureus
  • Presenting Complaints:
    • A chronic discharging sinus is the commonest presenting symptom.
    • The onset of sinus may be traced back to an episode of acute osteomyelitis during childhood.
    • Often sinuses heal for short periods, only to reappear with each acute exacerbation.
    • Discharge: Quality of discharge varies from seropurulent to thick pus.
    • There may be a history of extrusion of small bone fragments from the sinus.
    • Pain: Pain is usually minimal but may become aggravated during acute exacerbations.
    • Generalized symptoms of infection such as fever etc., are present only during acute exacerbations.
       
  • Radiological Features:
    • Thickening and irregularity of the cortices
    • Patchy sclerosis
    • Bone cavity: This is seen as an area of rarefaction surrounded by sclerosis.
    • Sequestrum: It is a piece of dead bone, surrounded by infected granulation tissue. It is pathognomic of chronic osteomyelitis. This appears denser than the surrounding normal bone because the decalcification which occurs in normal bone, does not occur in dead bone. Granulation tissue surrounding the sequestrum gives rise to a radiolucent zone around it. A sequestrum may be visible in soft tissues. It acts as nidus of infection and is the most common cause of non-healing sinus in chronic osteomyelitis. A chronic persistent neutrophilic discharge may be seen.
    • Involucrum is the dense sclerotic bone overlying a sequestrum formed from deep layers of stripped periosteum. It is usually obvious by the end of 2nd week.
    • If infection persists, pus and tiny sequestrated spicules of bone may continue to discharge from the perforations called cloacae.

 

 

  • Rim sign is seen on MRI.

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Treatment of chronic osteomyelitis is primarily surgical.
    • Paprika sign is the appearance of the live bone after removal of sequestrum.
       

 

  • Antibiotics are useful only during acute exacerbations and during postoperative period.
  • Various surgical options are:
    • Sequestrectomy
    • Saucerisation
    • Curettage
    • Excision of an infected bone
    • Amputation

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ewing’s sarcoma. Ewing sarcoma is the fourth most common primary malignancy of bone, but it is the second most common (after osteosarcoma) in patients younger than 30 years of age and the most common in patients younger than 10 years of age. Its maximum incidence is seen in 2nd decade of life. Pain is an almost universal complaint of patients. In addition to pain, patients also may have fever, erythema, and swelling suggesting osteomyelitis. Laboratory studies may reveal increased WBC count, an elevated ESR, and an elevated CRP. Classically, Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction. Ewing sarcoma more often originates in the metaphysis of a long bone, but frequently extends for a considerable distance into the diaphysis. Lung is the most common site of metastases. The worst prognostic factor is the presence of distant metastases. Even with aggressive treatment, patients with metastases have only a 20% chance of long-term survival. The treatment include neoadjuvant or adjuvant chemotherapy, or both, to treat distant metastases. Chemotherapy is much more effective and include vincristine, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, bleomycin, adriamycin, ifosfamide and etoposide.

 

  • ABCD: Actinomycin D / Bleomycin / Cyclophosphamide / Doxorubicin
  • Best results are achieved by Preoperative chemotherapy; then wide excision (or amputation) if tumor is in favorable site and further chemotherapy for 1 year. Subsequently Radiotherapy may be given.

 

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option D. Stress fracture of tibia. A tibial shaft stress fracture is an overuse injury where normal or abnormal bone is subjected to repetitive stress, resulting in microfractures. It is commonly seen in runners. There is linear microfracture in trabecular bone from repetitive loading. The patient have pain directly over the fracture which initially worsen after running. Diagnosis can often be made on radiographs alone but MRI studies should be obtained in patients with normal radiographs with a high degree of suspicion for stress fracture. Lateral x-ray shows dreaded black line anteriorly, endosteal thickening, periosteal reaction with cortical thickening. Treatment is activity restriction with protected weight-bearing in most cases. Surgical intramedullary nailing is recommended in the presence of an anterior tibia tension-sided stress fracture ("dreaded black line").

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The radiological image shown in the question and the clinical symptoms described are suggestive of chronic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: A patient after a roadside trauma presented to the trauma center. He has a severe pain in his left hip and, on examination the hip is exquisitely tender with restricted range of motion. The patient is lying in the posture seen below. Which of the following deformity is seen in the patient? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior dislocation of hip

 

ANTERIOR DISLOCATION OF HIP

 

  • Anterior dislocations occur with the hip externally rotated and abducted.

 

 

FABER position of limb after dislocation

 

  • The degree of flexion at the time of injury determines the eventual position of the femoral head.
  • They are associated with lengthening.
  • It is less common than posterior dislocation
  • It is divided into various types according to the position assumed by the femoral head: 
    • Pubic
    • Obturator
    • Perineal
       
  • Clinical Features:
    • Patient assumes externally rotated, abducted and slightly flexed posture at the affected hip, with restriction of movement.
    • Head of femur is often felt either anteriorly (superior type) or in the groin (inferior type).
       
  • Imaging Findings
    • Dislocation is usually seen on AP view; in a few cases, lateral view may be needed to establish the diagnosis.

 

 

  • Treatment: 
    • An anterior dislocation usually can be reduced without surgery by pulling longitudinally on the thigh.
    • If the dislocation cannot be reduced by these maneuvers, open reduction is performed.
       
  • Complication: 
    • Avascular necrosis.
    • Because of their anterior relationship to the hip, the femoral vessels and nerve may be injured, especially with pubic dislocations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior dislocation of hip. The head of the femur is pushed out of the acetabulum posteriorly. It is more common (90%). The injury is sustained by violence directed along the shaft of the femur, with the hip flexed in motor accidents. It is, therefore, also known as dashboard injury.

 

 

The patient presents with a history of severe trauma followed by pain, swelling and deformity (flexion, adduction and internal rotation – FADIR), associated with a shortening of the leg.

 

 

In plain radiograph, the femoral head is out of the acetabulum.

 

 

The thigh is internally rotated so, the lesser trochanter is not seen. Shenton’s line is broken. In most cases, it is possible to reduce the hip by closed manipulation under general anaesthesia. Open reduction may be required in cases where closed reduction fails, if there is intra-articular loose fragment, and if the acetabular fragment is large and is from the weight-bearing part of the acetabulum. Complications include injury to the sciatic nerve, avascular necrosis of the femoral head, osteoarthritis, myositis ossificans.

 

Option C. Inferior dislocation of hip. Inferior dislocation of hip or luxatio erecta femoris is the rarest among all types of hip dislocation. It can be caused by a severe trauma to the hip. Most of the reported cases involve the pediatric age group. There are two types of inferior hip dislocation; ischial type and obturator type. In the obturator type, when a force is applied to femur while the hip joint is in abduction and flexion, the femoral head dislocates anteriorly and inferiorly to the obturator foramen. In the ischial type, a force is applied to femur while hip and knee joints are in hyperflexion without abduction or external rotation. The femoral head dislocates inferiorly next to the ischium. The ischial type is more common than the obturator type.

 

 

Option D. Central dislocation of hip. A central dislocation involves the femoral head being forced downward. Acetabular fractures with central hip dislocation result from direct axial loading through the greater trochanter in abduction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Restricted hip range of motion with FABER deformity of the hip is suggestive of anterior dislocation of the hip.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to a stab wound to the chest. Breath sounds are diminished in the left lung and normal in the right lung. Heart sounds are normal. The jugular veins are flat. Focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) reveals left-sided intrathoracic free fluid. A left-sided chest tube is placed with immediate output of 2,000 mL of blood. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Emergent thoracotomy

questions.text: A 46-year-old female patient undergoes a mammography for a lump in the right breast. Based on the imaging report, she is advised to undergo a biopsy. Which of the following could have been reported?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) BIRADS 4b or BIRADS 5 

 

These categories indicate suspicious findings on mammography that strongly warrant a biopsy. BIRADS 4b signifies moderate suspicion of malignancy, while BIRADS 5 suggests a high likelihood of cancer (>95%), necessitating tissue diagnosis through biopsy.

 

Other options:
 

Option A. BIRADS 1 or 2: Negative or benign findings, not warranting biopsy.
 

Option B. BIRADS 2 or 3: Benign or probably benign lesions, with BIRADS 3 usually managed by short-term follow-up rather than biopsy.
 

Option C. BIRADS 3 or 4c: BIRADS 3 usually suggests follow-up; BIRADS 4c has high suspicion but less than 5.

 

Therefore, biopsy is recommended for lesions categorized as BIRADS 4b and above

 

BIRADS ASSESSMENT ALGORITHM:

choices.text: High Urine Calcium to Creatinine Ratio

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about nutritional Rickets?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) High Urine Calcium to Creatinine Ratio

 

In nutritional rickets, the typical biochemical profile shows normal or low serum calcium (due to compensatory rise in PTH), high parathyroid hormone, and low serum phosphorus (due to PTH-induced phosphaturia). Importantly, the urine calcium to creatinine ratio is low, not high, because hypocalcemia triggers increased renal calcium reabsorption, thus lowering urinary calcium excretion. A high ratio would be seen in hypercalciuria, which is not a feature of untreated nutritional rickets.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal Serum Calcium: Serum calcium is often normal or slightly low in nutritional rickets due to secondary hyperparathyroidism compensating for low dietary intake or malabsorption.

 

Option B. High Parathyroid Hormone: Secondary hyperparathyroidism is a classic response to hypocalcemia or vitamin D deficiency, so PTH levels are elevated.

 

Option C. Low Serum Phosphorus: Low phosphate is a result of PTH-induced phosphaturia, making this a typical feature of nutritional rickets

questions.solution: Ans. C) Closed Reduction + internal fixation

questions.text: All of the following are components of UW solution except :
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thymine

 

Thymine is not a component of the University of Wisconsin (UW) solution.

 

Other components include:

 

  • Allopurinol: A free-radical scavenger that helps reduce oxidative damage.
  • Glutathione: An antioxidant that protects cell membranes during cold storage.
  • Lactobionate: An impermeant that helps maintain osmotic balance and prevents cellular edema.

 

Thus, thymine is the exception and not part of the UW solution composition.

questions.solution: Ans. C) Figure of 8 bandage

choices.text: Depends on morphology rather than location

questions.text: Resection is performed for tears in which of the following locations?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C

 

Resection (partial meniscectomy) is performed for tears located in the inner third of the meniscus (area C, the “white-white” zone), which is avascular and has poor healing potential with repair. Because this area does not have sufficient blood supply, suturing or repairing tears here results in a very low chance of healing; hence, the torn portion is usually trimmed and removed to relieve symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A (Red-red zone): This is the outer third of the meniscus, which has the best blood supply and healing capacity. Tears in this region are best managed with repair (suturing), to preserve meniscal tissue.

 

Option B. B (Red-white zone): This is the middle third, has partial vascularity, and some tears here may heal if repaired, although the success rate is lower than in the red-red zone. Decision depends on tear morphology and age.

 

Option D. Depends on morphology rather than location: While tear morphology is important, location remains the primary factor guiding the choice between repair and resection—especially with regard to vascularity and healing potential

questions.text: Identify the type of Salter-Harris injury:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type 2

 

The X-ray shows a fracture extending through the growth plate (physis) and into the metaphysis, without involving the epiphysis. This is characteristic of a Salter-Harris Type 2 injury, which is also the most common type of physeal fracture. The presence of a metaphyseal fragment (Thurston Holland fragment) is pathognomonic for Type 2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type 1: Type 1 is a fracture strictly through the physis (growth plate) without involving either the metaphysis or epiphysis.

 

Option C. Type 3: Type 3 injuries extend through the physis and into the epiphysis, entering the joint space, which is not seen here.

 

Option D. Type 4: Type 4 fractures involve the metaphysis, physis, and epiphysis all together, passing “through” all three layers

choices.text: Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy

questions.text: An 45-year old female comes to your clinic reporting feelings of constant fatigue. Upon performing USG, you discover that she has a scleroatrophic gallbladder containing impacted stones. In addition, a 6mm stone is detected within the common bile duct, causing dilation of the biliary tree. What should be the subsequent course of action in her treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ERCP

 

  • The patient has a common bile duct stone (choledocholithiasis) with biliary dilation, which can lead to cholangitis or pancreatitis if left untreated.
  • Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is the first-line therapeutic procedure for CBD stone removal before cholecystectomy.
  • After CBD clearance, elective cholecystectomy is performed to prevent recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy – Performing surgery without addressing the CBD stone risks retained stone complications, including cholangitis or pancreatitis.

 

Option C. Elective cholecystectomy – Correct only after CBD clearance via ERCP; otherwise, patient remains at risk.

 

Option D. MRCP – Diagnostic only; not therapeutic. ERCP both diagnoses and treats CBD stones. Useful when the diagnosis is exact doubtful on USG.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male arrives at the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. The patient's vital signs are stable, and a focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) is ordered. All of the following may be missed on eFAST except?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Pneumothorax
